characters: PHOTO OF LIZA AND HER FATHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind the wheel:  JERRY FLETCHER.  Flat-out handsome if not for his eyes.  Someone rash, someone making an uninformed decision might call them crazy eyes.  He stops across from an apartment building, TOOTS his HORN.

dialogues.speaker: IN DOORWAY
dialogues.text: A woman and a man, a CYNIC, appear.  Jerry smiles as they kiss goodnight.  A bit of desperate passion.  She watches after him as he gets in the cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luxembourg Towers on 7th.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry nods, rolls out.  The Cynic watches the door to 1257 close, then sighs.  Jerry looks at him in the rearview.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sound of love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry exhales an exaggerated sigh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Love?  Love's just a pretty way of saying, 'I want to sleep with you'.  Love is bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I live on tips, so don't be offended, but you're a liar.  I saw you kiss.  Admit it, this is the street where love lives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Cynic looks back over his shoulder.  Down love street.  As Jerry hangs a right, the Cynic faces forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Love gives you wings.  It makes you fly.  I don't even call it love.  I call it Geronimo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Geronimo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Geronimo.  When you're really in love, you'll jump.  Off the top of the Empire State.  Screaming 'Geronimo' the whole way down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you'll die.  You'll squash yourself.  What's the point?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you listening, man?  Love gives you wings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Cynic just smiles, leans back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She must be some girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love her so bad.  She just... wrecks me.  I would die for her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry stops at a light.  A road crew are at work ahead. A white strobe light warns motorists that they're here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She feel the same about you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry can't take his eyes off the stroke.  As he blinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking down as a man's arms are strapped to the arm of a chair.  The POV JERKING UP as the same is done with the head.  A kaleidoscope of flashing lights ahead, then darkness as eyes are shut.  They're forced open.  We see the reflection of blue eyes in glass as they're taped open.  As bright lights strobe...

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO TAXI
dialogues.text: Jerry stares at the light, transfixed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never told her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why the hell not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I, uh, I have some problems.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The traffic light glows green; Jerry doesn't see it.  The sound of conspiratorial WHISPERS fill the taxi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The contents of a syringe pumped into the strapped arm. The walls begin to melt.  The WHISPERS CONTINUE. GARBLED, but their tone is perfectly clear.  Threatening. Cabalistic.  Human forms appear.  Stretched impossibly long, melting along with the walls. We CLOSE ON the reflection of a dozen pair of the same taped-open eyes.  The WHISPERING CUTS SHORT.  Ominously. The eyes dart from side-to-side as FOOTSTEPS approach. The eyes suddenly widen in agony.  As Jerry's scream of pain becomes the BLARE of a HORN, we find ourselves back in the...

dialogues.speaker: TAXI
dialogues.text: Going about 60 mph.  Jerry snaps to just in time to avoid a head-on collision with a car coming the other way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you crazy?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guy came right at us!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You turned up a one way street!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry watches, in a sweat, as he passes a "ONE WAY" sign pointing the opposite way.  He mutters to himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was only going one way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drop me off here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I'm sorry --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just drop me off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry pulls to the curb.  The meter at $3.60.  The Cynic slides a twenty through the slot and is out the door. Jerry watches over his shoulder as the Cynic disappears down the street.  Jerry rubs his eyes, tries to regroup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Love street...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Late.  The cab rolls, this time the right way.  Ahead, a well-dressed man steps off the curb, flags Jerry down.

dialogues.speaker: CAB
dialogues.text: Jerry slows, stops.  As the well-dressed man starts over, Jerry sizes him up.  The man seems suddenly sinister. As he reaches for the door, LOCKS CLICK DOWN.  Jerry GUNS the CAB away.  The confused man stumbles back, shouts, apparently not a threat at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Headlights out, the cab pulls up to the curb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry glances at a lit 2nd floor apartment window, then settles in with a bologna sandwich.  About to take a bite, he pauses, removes a slice of bologna.  He regards it a beat, then carefully peels off the edge.  Jerry holds the narrow casing up against the glow of a streetlight, like it was encoded.  Then something catches his eye.  He trades the sandwich for binoculars, focuses on the window.

dialogues.speaker: WINDOW
dialogues.text: LIZA SUTTON.  In a Yale sweatshirt, stretching, earphones on.  She forces her head past her kneecap and holds it there.  Driven is the word to describe Liza.  When she sleeps, she tries to do it better than anyone else does. We can't hear her, but as she finishes stretching, she sings along with the music on her headset.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: captivated, he sighs -- the sound of love.  Then he gets an idea.  Still watching, he fumbles for the RADIO. Turning it ON, he SCANS radio STATIONS.

dialogues.speaker: LIZA
dialogues.text: Her lips don't match anything.  COUNTING CROWS.  DAVID BOWIE.  The TRAFFIC REPORT.  A RAP TUNE.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: Never takes his eyes off her, SCANS STATIONS for the elusive number.  He finds ANNIE LENNOX singing "Blue Moon."

dialogues.speaker: LIZA
dialogues.text: Lips in synch.  That's what she's singing along with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (joins in) 'Blue moon, you saw me standing alone...'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INTERCUT between them.  "Without a song in my heart, without a love of my own.  Blue moon..."  In a weird way, it's a duet.  A sweet moment.  Then, Liza stops. She gets on a treadmill and cranks it up.  Walking a few moments before she's jogging, before she's running.  No easy pace here.  Liza gets grim, cranks up the speed and goes hard.  She's punishing herself.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: His voice trails off as he watches.  Sad, he lowers the binoculars, doesn't want to watch her do this.  Throwing the CAR in GEAR, he takes a last look and drives away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A classic corner newsstand except that a river runs down the street and over the curb.  Newspaper stacks usually on the sidewalk are up on milk crates.  The owner, FLIP TANNER, cruises the sidewalk in a battered wheelchair. All sinew and tendons, Flip is black, about 50.  He looks to Jerry's cab plowing twin fountains as it approaches. Flip heaves a stack of newspapers and magazines into his lap.  he rolls to meet Jerry at the curb, hands him the stack through the window.  Jerry looks down at the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Water main.  Broke all the way over on 40th Street and Seventh. Subway's a damn river.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry stares back over his shoulder at water gushing out a manhole cover.  Flip watches him, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What're you thinking, Jerry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Water mains usually go in the winter.  It's August 1st.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell you what.  Reminds me of life in the Delta.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mississippi?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mekong, my friend, Mekong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, Flip, Vietnam War was  fought because of a bet Howard Hughes lost to Aristotle Onasis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.  And the two of 'em used my legs for a wishbone.  Nearly snapped me in half.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta go, Flip.  Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Jerry drives away, Flip smiles, shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carrying his magazines and newspapers, Jerry climbs onto the roof from the fire escape.  He deadpans a look back and forth.  All seems clear.  Jerry starts across.  COOS as Jerry passes a PIGEON coop.  He steps back, opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's your choice, fellas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Jerry continues...

dialogues.speaker: SPACE BETWEEN TWO ROOFTOPS
dialogues.text: As Jerry leaps, PASSES directly OVER us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry enters by a window at the fire escape.  Apartment 202.  He checks the seam between the door and casing. The tip of a toothpick is just visible.  Assured, he unlocks the door.  As the toothpick drops, Jerry steps inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stacked with filled-to-bursting file cabinets.  On the walls, a silvery particle board.  Jerry locks the door, balances an empty beer bottle upside down on the door knob. Satisfied, Jerry enters the file labyrinth.  As he moves we FLASH ON some of the labels, some with not bad cartoon drawings.  "George Bush," "Delta 30," "Blue Flood," "Sirhan2." Jerry turns the corner.  "Nazis & Nutrasweet," "Patti Hearst," and among many more:  "MK Ultra" which features the silhouette of a man holding a handgun & "Council On Foreign Affair" with the C-F-A in heavily Gothic lettering.

dialogues.speaker: KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Locked.  Padlocked chains run through steel rings bolted to the sides.  Jerry spins the combo-lock.  Before opening, he pauses to consider a set of magnetic poetry words on the fridge door.  He arranges them, reads:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The essential goddess death could chain bitter men, (moves words) and crush the ugly moment... like life pounding eggs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry opens the fridge to reveal ten padlocked stainless steel containers.  He removes one labeled:  "Tapioca."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carrying a bowl of tapioca, Jerry enters.  More files, a manual typewriter.  On the wall, an American flag alongside a poster of John Lennon reading:  "Assassinated
He strides to his desk and a...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry scans a New York Times spread on a drafting table. He circles headlines, names and dates.  Does the same with the San Francisco Chronicle, Le Monde, Time, the Economist and Popular Mechanics.  He enters raw data on 3x5 cards:  space shuttle launched, base closings, escape from mental hospital and especially the obituaries. Specifically:  "Industrialist Ernest Hariman Drowns." Jerry flips through 100s of cards on big Rolodexes as he cross-references data.  Jerry pulls cards, lines them up. The first connection:  the dates of six Space Shuttle launches and six earthquakes all coinciding.  Jerry lets out a low whistle.  Never too jaded to be shocked. Jerry types the text of an article, crosses out mistakes. He handcranks copies off an old drum mimeograph.  The hand drawn logo:  lips whispering into an ear.  The title:  "Conspiracy Theory." Jerry writes out five labels.  Addresses from across America.  Jerry slaps the labels on the newsletters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun comes up. Jerry drops the newsletters into a mailbox.  He starts across the street, then stops, looks back with dread.  He steps back over, checks the slot.  Everything went down. Jerry starts away, then stops again.  As he looks back...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry passes through the metal detectors.  He stops to stare at the blindfolded Status of Justice.  As a FEDERAL COP steps over to join him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smart girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's that, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's got a blindfold on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have an appointment here, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry continues to stare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Depends on your definition...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The morning meeting yet to begin.  Lawyers wait as, THROUGH the glass, treadmill girl Liza Sutton argues with brusque department head WILSON.  It's a screaming match, though on this side of the glass their VOICES are MUFFLED THUMPS.  Liza waves her arms.  Wilson shakes his head emphatically. As they continue to argue, a YOUNG LAWYER arrives being shown the ropes by an OLDER LAWYER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the conference room.  We start 9 AM sharp.  Usually.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The argument in the conference room has gotten so vociferous, that people have stopped pretending not to watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow.  How long till I can talk like that to Mr. Wilson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About a thousand years.  That's Liza Sutton.  You heard of the federal judge?  Tom Sutton? Assassinated a few years ago?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By that cult leader who's in prison, right?  Ezekiel Walters. The one who blew up the Citibank Building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: None of it ever proven.  But Sutton did deny Ezekiel a writ of habeas corpus.  Anyhow, Liza is Sutton's daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A commotion down the hall.  Jerry.  The cop from  downstairs and a second one try everything short of violence to usher him out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm an American and I demand to  see Liza Sutton!

dialogues.speaker: CONFERENCE ROOM
dialogues.text: Wilson and Liza are nose-to-nose.  THROUGH the glass, the head of every lawyer turns from them to Jerry.  Like deftly executed synchronized swimming, Liza and Wilson can't help but notice.  Jerry.  Liza shakes her head in despair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, your psychotic is here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not today...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liza crouches down on the floor behind the chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him I'm on vacation.  That I won't be back for two weeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know if you're the best lawyer I've got or a high school sophomore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wilson shakes his head, exits.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE CONFERENCE ROOM
dialogues.text: As Jerry struggles with the guards who are definitely getting more physical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get him out of here.

dialogues.speaker: CONFERENCE ROOM
dialogues.text: Liza peeks out.  They're hurting Jerry now.  As Liza sighs.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE CONFERENCE ROOM
dialogues.text: They drag Jerry back.  Liza appears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay!  Let him go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guards hesitate.  Wilson nods.  As they let Jerry go...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry, you are a restraining order waiting to happen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In its own way as cluttered and overflowing with files as Jerry's apartment is.  At her desk, Liza watches Jerry pace.  The door is intentionally open.  Liza's secretary JILL keeps a protective eye from the outer office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't see the connection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on!  Six major earthquakes in the last three years?  The space shuttle in orbit for every one of them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (incredulous) Testing some top secret seismic weapon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not testing.  Using.  Nukes are passe.  This is the weapon of the future.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Liza exchanges a look with Jill, Jerry pauses to look at a framed photo on a credenza. Liza, 20, in full riding gear, gracefully jumping a horse over a set of rails.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I still don't see what it has to do with the President.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re:  photo) Do you still ride?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not for years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So why do you keep the picture up? You wish you hadn't quit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I -- Jerry, the point.  Get there.  What does it have to do with the President?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It takes him a moment to switch gears.  Setting down the picture, he pulls out a map, unfolds it on Liza's desk. A seismic survey map.  He points as he talks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The President's in Europe. Tomorrow he'll be in Turkey. Right along this fault line.  They launched the space shuttle yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Motive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's cutting funding for NASA. The milk cow of the aerospace industry.  We're talking billions. Motive enough?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NASA is going to kill the President of the United States with an earthquake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods) Not exactly the kind of thing a Secret Service Agent can throw himself on top of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liza sighs.  On another day, Jerry might have been welcome comic relief.  Not today.  As she folds his map...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You going to warn him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't promise you anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think I'm crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you're different.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, to be 'normal' and live in the 'real world,' to swallow Coca cola and eat Kentucky Fried Chicken, you have to be in a conspiracy against yourself.  I can't lie to me, Liza.  And the more I strip through the sham, the crazier I look to people like you. Can't you see that's what they're counting on? (a beat) You want to go out sometime?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry smiles, looks away, embarrassed in an appealingly boyish way.  If he wasn't crazy, the answer might be yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I better get going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to burst in here every time, Jerry.  Just call and make an appointment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He nods, gathers his map.  Halfway out, he looks back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was your horse's name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnny Dancer. (a beat) You've been in my office ten times.  How come you never asked me about that picture before?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was waiting till I knew you better.  Johnny Dancer, huh? Sounds like a racehorse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry heads out.  Liza watches after him a beat as he goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cordoned off with cops redirecting traffic.  A lake.  Big diesel pumps gush water into the gutters, and the sidewalks are sandbagged.  All the same, water flows over Jerry's sneakers as he flags down a passing PUBLIC WORKS GUY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, don't water mains usually go in the winter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Summer, winter, all I know it it's beaucoup overtime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something catches Jerry's eye -- a tan sedan parked inside the cordon.  Official U.S. Government plates.  As Jerry frowns, two suits, CLARKE and PIPER, exit the subway kiosk, head to the sedan.  Jerry watches, then heads for his cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sedan pulls up, double parks.  As Piper and Clark head inside, Jerry pulls up across the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry enters, watches Clark and Piper get on the elevator for the 14th to 25th floors.  As the door closes, Jerry steps to a podium with a directory of the building's occupants.  He drops a finger onto a listing.  Floors 18 to 22 are occupied by:  the Central Intelligence Agency.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spooks.  I knew it.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: Grainy black and white as Jerry exits.  Is he being watched?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry's cab is reflected against the glass.  THROUGH the window, we see Jerry at the counter.  Standing, he throws a few bills down and exits. Jerry reappears in reflection, stops short as Piper is reflected on one side, Clark on the other.  They grab Jerry.  As he struggles Clark jams an air syringe against his neck.  Jerry's reflection goes slack. As they drag him into his cab, a single OLD MAN at the counter looks over, then back to his meatloaf as the yellow of the cab streaks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Strapped to a chair in the middle of what looks like an old hospital room.  Jerry's groggy, starting to regain consciousness.  As he comes round, we hear FOOTSTEPS APPROACHING from the hall.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: Two men enter.  They may or may not be Piper and Clark, but we only see their torsos as they move back and forth. We hear a CLOSET OPEN, EQUIPMENT being DRAGGED.  Jerry knows he's righteously fucked.  But he also knows...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was right.  Wasn't I?  I was right. (a beat) What was I right about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't seem to pay him any mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you guys from NASA?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without warning, one of the figures grabs Jerry's head from behind, straps it to a slat he attaches to the back of the chair. Jerry struggles, but his head is immobilized.  The second man goes about taping Jerry's eyes open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was wrong!  I was wrong!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finished, they leave.  Jerry struggles, then finally waits.  A new set of FOOTSTEPS in the hall.  Jerry's eyes follow someone into the room and across from him.  Jerry frowns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I know you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes you do, Jerry.  Quite well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WIDEN to include --

dialogues.speaker: JONAS
dialogues.text: Standing opposite Jerry.  Genteel looking, professorial. There's something calm, oddly soothing about him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you ever been in a place from which hope has gone?  All that's left is patience.  Everywhere. Like a fog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat as Jonas considers Jerry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a very patient man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's great.  Good for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who have you been talking to, Jerry?  Who else knows what you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could you be a little more specific?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonas doesn't answer.  Instead, he methodically loads a syringe.  Jerry watches with grave apprehension.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lysergic acid diethylamide... With a little kicker of my own.  Surely it must be coming back to you by now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's nowhere to go, but Jerry still tries to go there as the needle descends.  And then the plunge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do I know?...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonas switches on a row of strobe lights.  They flash into Jerry's face.  In between them, on a screen, images.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man on fire.  Kennedy with the waiter on the floor in the Ambassador.  That guy in Vietnam being shot in the side of the head.  Rhesus monkeys subjected to direct brain stimulation.  Reagan catching it under the armpit. A slaughterhouse.  And interspersed between it all, a rather official-looking photo of a middle-aged man we'll call Mr. S.  Then --

dialogues.speaker: JONAS
dialogues.text: is dancing back and forth before Jerry.  The strobes freeze him like some club from the '70s.

dialogues.speaker: ROOM
dialogues.text: But Jonas isn't really dancing.  He's directly across from Jerry -- profile-to-profile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who else knows what you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slack-jawed, Jerry doesn't answer.  Jonas holds an electrode to Jerry's leg, touches a second to his side. Jerry arches back as current flows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as the ceiling melts and drops in heavy globs around them.

dialogues.speaker: ROOM
dialogues.text: Jonas cuts the flow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who else knows what you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry's only answers are the tears running down his cheeks.  Jonas hits him again. Jerry jerks back so hard the chair snaps right off the floor and topples over backwards.  Jerry's left wrist and right leg burst through the straps which were holding them down.  A wisp of smoke rises. Jonas sighs.  He looks down at Jerry who moans, whispers...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonas smiles paternally, steps over.  Jerry's mouth moves, but we can't hear him.  Mr. S flashes on the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (crouching) From your lips, to God's ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Jonas leans in, his nose looks enormous.

dialogues.speaker: ROOM
dialogues.text: Grabbing Jonas' shirt with his limited left hand, Jerry uses the only weapon he's got.  He bites Jonas on the nose.  Blood pulses as Jerry's teeth find an artery. Howling, Jonas tries to scramble out of reach. Jerry kicks him in the stomach with his free leg and then keeps kicking.  It's inarticulate, roughshod work, but he connects and Jonas feels it and each new kick as a little more fury than the last. Finally Jonas rolls away.  Jerry half-crawls, half-rocks his way to a crouched position.  Rising, he staggers into the window, the top of the chair smashing through the glass.  Jerry stares down to the ground below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the earth rises and falls like a wave.  The distance down is impossible to gauge.

dialogues.speaker: ROOM
dialogues.text: As Jonas staggers to his feet, Piper and Clark charge in. They move forward, but without warning, Jerry gathers what balance he has and heaves himself out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Partially obscured by trees, Jerry does a half-gainer from exactly two stories above the ground.  The chair back takes the brunt of the landing.  Wood splinters.

dialogues.speaker: ROOM
dialogues.text: Blood spurts between Jonas' fingers.  Clark and Piper draw their guns and rush to the window...

dialogues.speaker: GROUND
dialogues.text: Slats of wood hang at his elbows and knees as Jerry reels across the lawn.

dialogues.speaker: ROOM
dialogues.text: Clark and Piper FIRE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't kill him!  Get him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Clark and Piper rush off...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry slogs, sinks into asphalt up to his knees.  A truck sets a dumpster down on the street ahead.  As it pulls away, Jerry dashes, grabs hold of a handle on the rear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the truck approach.  As it turns right, the  centrifugal force flings Jerry off the back and into the oncoming lane.  Several taxis slam on their brakes to keep from running him over. All Jerry sees is yellow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm one of you!  I'm one of you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As one driver leans out one window, shouts at him in Hindu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liza's in the back next to, but not with, one of the Lawyers seen earlier.  He seems nice enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, you doing anything tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hefts briefcase) Working.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmm, how about tomorrow night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Working.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Night after that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) Look, you're a nice guy, but I'm not really dating right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not that good at 'no,' Liza.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too bad.  Because I'm terrible at 'yes.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the elevator doors open, Liza steps into her worst nightmare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liza Sutton!  I need to see Liza!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry is being blocked by three FEDERAL COPS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't leave now, you're under arrest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Jerry spots her....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liza!  This is it.  They just tried to kill me!  I don't know what I know, but it's big!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They tangle him up, a few feet from his destination. Liza can see that something, real or imagined, has happened. In the struggle, Jerry wrenches free, taking one of the Cops' .45s with him.  He waves them off with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get back!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone freezes.  Stand-off city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy, Jerry.  Easy. (realizes) There's blood on your shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indeed, blood is splattered across his chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bit the bastard's nose off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bit someone's nose off?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes!  Don't let's get into this thing where I have to repeat myself!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As one of the Cops moves to flank, Jerry aims the gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Cops) It's a man without a nose you want, you dumb complicit sons of bitches! (to Liza) You've got to listen to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put down the gun and I'll take your statement.  Okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the boss.  Just don't make me repeat myself.  I hate that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liza sees blood dripping onto Jerry's shoe.  She looks to where he clutches his side, blood oozing out.  To his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry, you're bleeding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry takes his hand from his side, looks at the blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't even feel it till a few minutes ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Jerry's distracted, one of the Cops moves in.  He forces Jerry's gun hand up while the other two Cops take him down.  Jerry struggles till one jams a thumb into a pressure point in his neck.  Jerry winces, collapses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are they?  I don't even know who they are.  But it's on the tip of my tongue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Jerry starts to sob.  As Cop one cuffs him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of you call an ambulance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hesitation before one of them moves to do so.  Liza pushes her way through the other two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ease off of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They back off a step, keep him covered.  Jerry continues to sob, desolate.  And Liza, despite herself, puts an arm around him, does what she can to comfort.  Her life's never going to be the same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A definite inner city feel.  Liza stands out in her smart, stylish business suit.  She sits in a plastic chair, tries not to scream into her cell phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need the files tonight.  Have them sent to my apartment.  I don't give a rat's ass what you're doing!  Hello?  Damnit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phone's dead.  Sitting beside Liza, fidgety in the early stages of withdrawal, is DOLLY, a 20-year-old prostitute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sucks, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liza doesn't even look over.  Dolly holds up a pager.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should get one of these.  Then use a pay phone.  Cell phones can be traced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not doing anything illegal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dolly looks her over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bedraggled DOCTOR enters, scans the waiting faces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's here for Jerry Fletcher?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (standing) I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Doctor steps over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's lucky.  Bullet passed clean through his side, didn't touch anything vital.  He lost some blood, but he should be fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When can I talk to him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're moving him to the police ward.  Maybe in twenty minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Doctor's already on his way out.  Liza sits back down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're lucky.  I had a boyfriend get shot in the stomach.  Now he takes a dump through a plastic tube.  I guess that's life, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liza reaches into her day planner, pulls out a crisp $100 bill, holds it out to Dolly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's yours.  Just go sit someplace else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dolly looks at her a beat.  Plucking the bill from Liza's fingertips, Dolly gets up and moves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cop reads the paper at the end of the hall.  He barely looks up as Liza walks down, steps into...

dialogues.speaker: ROOM 322
dialogues.text: Liza enters as a NURSE injects a syringeful of "something" into Jerry's IV.  Jerry's strapped to the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something to help you sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to sleep!  I want to be checked out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're under arrest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry looks over at Liza as the Nurse exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the charge?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were there, Jerry.  Figure it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He nods.  Is quiet a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you could remember who shot you and where it happened, it might help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry's suddenly fighting to keep his eyes open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a day.  Wish I could tell you so it made sense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tries to sit up.  She eases him back down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just relax.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Switch the charts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry's as serious as a guy about to pass out can be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Switch 'em.  Or I'll be dead by morning.  Don't want to be dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll see you tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Jerry eases back into the mattress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wouldn't bet on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Liza starts to go...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey... (as Liza looks back) I can't control it.  It's just, something that happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look at each other a moment.  Then, as Jerry's eyes flutter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Switch 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long sigh and Jerry's out.  Liza starts out, then stops, laughs at herself as she realizes what she needs to do.  Stepping over, she switches the chart at the foot of Jerry's bed with that of his unconscious roommate. This guy's handcuffed to the bed frame. Liza looks at Jerry a beat, sighs, then exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back on the treadmill.  Liza practically sprints.  Her teeth grit.  Driven near collapse.  Like she's punishing herself.  As we PULL BACK, leaving her to her demons...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The next day.  Liza, arriving, stops short as an orderly flanked by a COP, wheels a sheet-covered body out of 322.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guy came in with a gunshot wound, but he died of a heart attack.  Go figure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fearing the worst, Liza pulls back the sheet.  It's Jerry's roommate.  The guy who got Jerry's chart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you Miss Sutton?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liza looks up, nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They said send you downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The F.B.I., the C.I.A.  You name the initials and they're down there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any special reason?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All I know is, they said to send you and the body to the basement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They think the dead guy is Jerry.  Liza eyes the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be right down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry sits in bed, one hand cuffed to the bed rail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People do have heart attacks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.  You switched the charts, didn't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liza doesn't answer.  Jerry jubilant.  This is big.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay.  The guy traded bullets with some old man in a liquor store.  He had it coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You expect me to believe what, that someone came in here last night.  Gave that guy... something that stopped his heart?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You switched the charts; you tell me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got to get downstairs.  The C.I.A., they want to see your body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nods.  Jerry regards the cuff, then her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't be here when you get back, but I'll be in touch.  And thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You saved my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heart attacks happen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liza exits.  Jerry thinks, smiles.  He dips his hand into his oatmeal, smears it across his chin, onto his chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liza steps off the elevator, is met by AGENT LOWRY. Darkly handsome, Lowry is all business with a twinkly in his eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ms. Sutton?  Agent Lowry, F.B.I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They shake hands.  Both impressed with each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're waiting for jurisdictional problems to be cleared up.  This guy Fletcher's something else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While we walk. (they move briskly) D.C. police want him for assault. Secret Service for counterfeiting and we're tracking him on a string of bank robberies.  No one knows what the C.I.A. wants him for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait --

dialogues.speaker: OPERATING THEATER
dialogues.text: Lowry enters ahead of her.  The body is here.  All backs are to Lowry and Liza.  Wilson from Justice looks back over his shoulder.  The other five are CIA.  One man stands a bit apart.  Lowry points him out, whispers into Liza's ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guy's a C.I.A. shrink.  Here to I.D. Fletcher.  They knew each other somehow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't understand --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lowry shushes her.  The sheet is pulled away to reveal Jerry's roommate.  His back still to us, the CIA PSYCHIATRIST is not happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning) Liza?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Psychiatrist takes the chart from the foot of the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was trying to tell, um, Jerry, I mean Fletcher, he's --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liza stops short as the Psychiatrist turns around.  His nose is bandaged.  His eyes look right through her.  It's Jonas!  Jerry's man with no nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Covered in oatmeal, Jerry clutches his chest, groans. Three nurses, two orderlies and an INTERN surround him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's having a heart attack!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Intern tugs on the handcuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's that goddamn cop?! (giving up) Get a crash cart in here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!  Get me to the crash cart!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liza, Jonas, Lowry, Wilson and the CIA agents get into the elevator.  Liza can't take her eyes off Jonas's nose. He looks over at her.  It's unnerving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I ask you something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dog bit it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were going to ask about my nose.  The poor animal is slated to be destroyed today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you feel bad for it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was my dog.  Let me ask you a question.  How long have you been acquainted with Jerry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A crash.  The Intern staggers back out the door and into the wall.  Jerry exits -- wearing a johnny which flaps as he dashes down the hall.  Bouncing along behind him is the bed's side rail which he's still cuffed to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry pounds on the down button.  PING!  The doors on the middle elevator open to reveal Liza, Jonas, et. al... They spot Jerry the same moment he spots them. Jerry drives the rail into one agent's gut, staggering him.  The second agent trying to exit catches the rail in the teeth.  The elevator doors close.

dialogues.speaker: ELEVATOR
dialogues.text: Lowry reaches for the control panel.  But he's too late. As the elevator starts up, Lowry slaps the emergency stop.  Then they pull the doors open.  The various agents climb out, step down to the 3rd floor hallway below. Jerry is nowhere in sight.  But from the hallway to the right of the elevators, a SHOUT and a CRASH.  Everyone heads that way.

dialogues.speaker: NURSES' STATION
dialogues.text: A nurse stands over an upended Med-Cart.  She looks up at Liza and the suits charging around the corner.  Points. PILLS CRUNCH under their feet as they take off in pursuit.

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY TWO
dialogues.text: Jerry pulls a chair cover, hops up and punches a ceiling panel loose.  Then he continues down the hall. The gang round the corner, stop short at the chair and panel.  Jonas motions two agents up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rest of you go room to room! I want dogs!  I want motion detectors!  I want heat sensors!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Jonas moves off, Lowry mutters to Liza.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this guy a psychiatrist or a field agent?

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY THREE
dialogues.text: A row of beds against the wall.  An orderly dumps a load of laundry down a laundry chute.  He leaves.  Jerry exits a bathroom, heads over.  Gripping the lip of the chute, he's just swung a leg inside when the room COP appears around the corner, gun drawn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put your foot down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you knew what really happened to Serpico, you'd be doing everything you could to help me out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (closing) Put your damn foot down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Obliging, Jerry swings his leg back over.  But he sets his heel on a laundry cart, shoves it hard into the Cop. It gives Jerry a chance to swing the bed rail into the Cop whose gun skitters away as he tumbles back. Jerry tries again to jump down the laundry chute, but the Cop is there, grapples with him.  Jerry finally head- butts him.  As the Cop falls back, releasing Jerry, Jerry falls down the chute.  He jerks to a stop as the bed rail forms a crossbar over the mouth of the chute.

dialogues.speaker: LAUNDRY CHUTE
dialogues.text: Jerry dangles from his wrist.  That hurt. Jamming his back against one side of the chute, his feet against the other, he inches his way up.  As he grips the edge to get out, a face looms!  Liza.  Jerry loses his grip again, drops, jerks to another joint-wrenching stop.

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY THREE
dialogues.text: Liza stands beside the semi-conscious Cop, looks down at Jerry.  He looks up at her.  At her mercy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He says a dog bit his nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arf... You gotta help me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't promise you anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liza turns, hears PEOPLE COMING her way.  Deciding, she takes the key ring from the cop's belt, finds the handcuff key.  She slides it into the cuff on Jerry's wrist. They share a long look.  Click.  Jerry drops.  Liza's left holding the rail.  She turns, sees the beds by the wall.

dialogues.speaker: LAUNDRY ROOM
dialogues.text: Jerry lands hard in a hamper.

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY THREE
dialogues.text: Liza tends to the Cop (returning his keys, pockets the cuffs) as Lowry and Jonas turn the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which way did he go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  Didn't see him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the Cop starts to sit up groggily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No way we can shut a place this size down quick enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have a half-naked man chained to a bed rail.  Just cover the exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lowry nods, heads out.  Liza follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll come with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonas looks over at the lone bed rail, then across at the laundry chute.  Finally at Liza's retreating back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liza stops, looks back.  Jonas crooks a finger at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep me company.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry the doctor.  In his scrubs, pulls on a paper hair net.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two cops on watch at the exits.  Three tired interns on the way out when Jerry joins them.  Just one of the guys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you see that spleen?  I never saw a spleen like that ever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cops don't give them a second look as they exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Odd looks from the interns, but Jerry's home free.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was unbespleenable!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonas dips a tea bag, stares across at Liza who grinds out a cigarette in an overflowing ashtray.  He watches as she goes for her pack, realizes that was her last butt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So he thinks NASA is plotting to kill the President?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You already asked me that.  Why do you insist on making me repeat myself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you have no idea where he lives?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've asked me that one three times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's a fresh one.  Why you? Your colleague Mr. Wilson says Jerry won't speak to anyone else. That seems oddly possessive behavior to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.  What was the question again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honestly?  I think he has a crush on me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A charming term.  Now, why him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry's visits to your office. Why do you tolerate them?  Why him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A year ago I was leaving work late one night.  Two guys tried to mug me.  It was horrible.  Jerry came out of nowhere.  To my rescue. Then he started coming to see me. (smiles) Could've been a storybook if he wasn't crazy.  At first I did my beat to avoid him.  But there's something inside Jerry and... (shrugs) Jerry made me see it.  He made me see him.  That make sense?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonas nods.  As he tends to his tea, Liza notices he wears a Harvard alumni ring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You went to Harvard?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonas nods.  Liza gestures toward the ring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonas offers his hand so she can get a closer look: three open books with the letters VE-RI-TAS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Veritas.  Truth.  What is it they say about truth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The truth shall make you free.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it. (releases his hand) I went to Yale.  I hope you won't hold that against me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only on the football field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's as charming as Jonas gets.  The sparring continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't know the C.I.A. had psychiatrists.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're very specialized.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brain washing, mind control, that sort of thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Re-educating trained killers in the ways of polite society. Making sure the men who've gone over the edge won't hurt anyone. That sort of thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonas takes a sip of tea, watches her over the rim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cop at the door.  Liza flashes her ID, enters.  She heads to the nightstand, opens it.  There's a key ring, a pack of gum and a worn paperback copy of Catcher In the Rye with the familiar crimson and gold cover.  Liza flips through it.  Certain passages are highlighted, others blacked out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Catcher In the Rye?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liza looks up as Agent Lowry enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the book Hinkley had on him when he shot Reagan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just thinking that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leaning in) You remember that Arab guy who shot the Rabbi a few years back? (as they look over) I was one of the arresting officers.  He had a copy of the goddamn thing too. (smiles) You know that expression, it must be the water.  Well, maybe it's the book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the Cop laughs it up, Lowry and Liza exchange a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for your input, officer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Cop shrugs, exits.  Lowry picks up the keys and gum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gum, keys and a book. (checks keys) Car... Maybe apartment... This is an odd one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of the three keys, one is long and narrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Safety deposit box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Lowry nods, three of Jonas' CIA suits enter.  As one confiscates the gum and book, another holds his hand out for the keys.  Lowry gives them over.  As they exit...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're welcome! (shrugs to Liza) Spooks.  So, you want to compare notes on this guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  Not yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something catches Liza's eye.  She steps to the nightstand. A word is scratched into the side by the bed.  Geronimo. Lowry picks a fork off the floor.  Just the right size.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Geronimo?  What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liza exits, starts for the street.  A long day.  She fishes a small tape recorder from her briefcase, switches it on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry Fletcher.  Apparently, a major desperado.  Subject of a multi-jurisdictional task force manhunt... I don't buy it.  He might be nuts, but there's something... good about him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liza suddenly reacts in shock to something ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liza dashes forward.  We see her car at the curb -- a BMW sedan.  A traffic control officer has just finished shoving a ticket under the wiper.  Liza arrives shouting, as they roll away.  Liza grabs the ticket, pissed, frustrated.  But after a moment, she gets in the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gets in grumbling, STARTS the ENGINE.  As six fanned- out parking tickets rise from the back seat behind her, she spots them in the rearview.  Liza jumps, her grip on the steering wheel the only thing keeping her from hitting her head on the roof.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've been coming all day. Nothing I could do about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she recovers...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd you know this was my car?

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: He lies across the back seat, staring up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucky guess... Um, I'd feel a lot less naked if we could get outta here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't tell me you're naked back there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Figure of speech.  Could we go?

dialogues.speaker: BMW
dialogues.text: Liza takes the tickets.  Deciding, she hits the gas, starts through the intersection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What took so long?  You were in there all day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's how long it takes to turn a hospital inside out.  A lot of people are after you, Jerry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dead or alive, they'll stick me in  there with Oswald.  Another lunatic acting alone,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oswald was an assassin.  You're not an assassin, are you, Jerry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're worried about the President, call and warn him about the Space Shuttle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.  Sit up so I can see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh uh, don't want them to see me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Them who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Change lanes.  Then watch your  rearview.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liza does so.  Looking in the mirror, a set of headlights, maybe three cars back, move as well.  Liza frowns, turns left, eyes on the mirror.  A beat and the car follows her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flat, wraparound headlights?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crown Victoria.  F.B.I. car.  A legitimate tail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As opposed to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People more serious about their work. You know how to drive this thing or do you just like looking good in it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean I should speed up and try and lose them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's how a man would do it.  I'm not a man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I noticed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liza stops in the middle of the street.  Jerry stays low.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: STREET
dialogues.text: The Crown Victoria has slowed considerably.  Liza sticks her arm out of the window of the BMW, motions it forward.

dialogues.speaker: CROWN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Lowry at the wheel.  Knows he's been made.  No use trying to get out of it now.  Shaking his head, he rolls forward.

dialogues.speaker: STREET
dialogues.text: Lowry pulls up alongside Liza.  Can't see Jerry in back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agent Lowry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugs; sheepish) Wasn't my idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonas?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's his show for now.  Look, you want to get some dinner?  Inter- Agency cooperation and all?

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: in the back.  He doesn't like the sound of that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liza smiles, but isn't biting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I'm ready to compare notes, I'll let you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your call.  Have a good night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lowry puts it in gear and takes off.  Relieved, Jerry sits up, watches the taillights fade away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See?  Wasn't that a lot easier than squealing tires and knocking over trash cans?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing is easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long have we known each other, Jerry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six months.  Eleven days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Till today, I haven't believed a word.  Now, I'm curious.  Six months, eleven days.  I'm going to give you one more hour to impress me.  Where to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flip watches from his wheelchair as the BMW pulls up.  It takes him a minute to recognize...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry?  You didn't show last night.  First time ever.  Had me worried, boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, Flip. (re:  Liza) Got sidetracked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flip glances at Liza, thinks he understands.  As he winks at Jerry, Liza rolls her eyes to the heavens.  Flip retrieves a double stack of newspapers and magazines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saved you last night's, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flip was a hero in Vietnam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure was.  Pounded the V.C. for this Greek cat named Ari Onasis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flip smiles as he wheels back over.  He likes Jerry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry and Liza by the window.  Jerry hands her the front page of The New York Times.  As Jerry scarfs bread...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just look at it.  Ten seconds and you'll be scared out of your mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Liza scans the paper, a waiter sets a small salad in front of her and a big bowl of spaghetti and sausage in front of Jerry.  He digs in like a five-year-old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re:  salad) You worked all day for that? Lettuce, tomatoes, no dressing. That's what, you're punishing yourself, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks up.  An odd beat.  Is Jerry on to something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have the right to ask me certain personal questions?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slurps noodles) Yeah.  I think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liza hands him back the paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing scary there.  Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, well, maybe to the untrained eye. (scans it) Hmm... Ahh... (raises eyebrows) Ooooo...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liza waits as Jerry spreads out the paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More about life on Mars.  From a  rock they found on the South Pole. Explain that one to me.  But maybe we should go to Mars and find out? How much do you think that's going to cost?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it with you and the space program?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And look here.  Cease fire in Chechenia.  That's good for the banks who lent the government money, but bad for the guys selling them weapons. (scanning article) Listen to this, some gas company in Colorado.  Their researchers have been blocked from testing a fuel additive.  They've accused the E.P.A. of, quote, 'turning a blind eye to the future.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry grabs a dollar bill from the tip of the adjacent table.  He turns it over, points out the "eye" above the pyramid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well that's the eye right there. Money.  And all the power and misery it brings with it. It's a plot to take over the world.  The Master Conspiracy. Can take a lifetime to pull off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do they have a secret handshake?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry takes her hand.  He shakes it, employing various complex machinations.  Finished, he regards her intently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She laughs.  He got her that time.  But after a beat...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So why are they after you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure.  I think I figured something out. (lowers voice) It must've been in my newsletter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What newsletter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry crosses his lips with his finger, shushes her.  He motions her forward so he can whisper.  She leans in. At that moment -- a GUNSHOT! In one motion, Jerry stands, throws his chair through the plate glass window.  As GLASS RAINS down, he's already got one foot out on the sidewalk.  He reaches back for Liza.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then Jerry sees the waiter, standing nearby, a bottle of wine in one hand, a popped cork in the other -- the source of the sound.  Jerry looks back to Liza.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I'm a little jumpy.  Who wouldn't be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're certifiable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wouldn't be sitting here if you didn't halfway believe me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Believe you about what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry shrugs.  As the manager storms over, Liza peels off a hundred dollar bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re:  window) Will that cover it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shakes his head.  As she peels off a few more...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know that hour you gave me to impress you?  How much of it is left?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liza enters by a window at the fire escape.  Jerry follows.  His side is obviously bothering him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flesh wound.  No big deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry heads for the door to his apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I still don't think we had to park a mile away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry and Liza enter.  Closing the door behind them, he switches on the light.  Liza looks from the filing cabinets to the silvery particle board covering the walls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this supposed to protect you from aliens?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry doesn't answer as he locks the door, picks the empty beer bottle up off the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know why the Grateful Dead are always on tour?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Surprise me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The whole kit and caboodle of 'em are British Intelligence agents. Spies.  Jerry Garcia had a double- o rating.  Just like James Bond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry sits the beer bottle on the doorknob, turns, heads off.  Liza looks at the bottle, then, "a la Bond"...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Garcia, Jerry Garcia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he moves to follow...

dialogues.speaker: FILE LABYRINTH
dialogues.text: They snake their way through the towering files.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want something to drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um, coffee.  If that's okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry looks back over his shoulder, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coffee's our friend.

dialogues.speaker: KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Liza watches as Jerry unchains the refrigerator.  He misinterprets the look on her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I keep the beans in the fridge. They stay fresher that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Jerry removes one of the stainless steel containers, Liza reads some of his magnetic poetry off the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Must language produce a thousand knives and not recall a whisper? (then another) I love the delicate shadow of she wanting me to be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liza smiles at Jerry who looks up sheepishly from the container.  He's having trouble with the lock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgot the combination... You want some grapefruit juice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry enters with Liza.  The photo of Lennon gives her pause.  She looks at the surrounding files then watches as Jerry turns the mimeograph drum, starts printing something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If my universe had a hub...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This would be it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry nods.  Liza steps to the drafting table where Jerry has done several rough, but competent sketches of horses in motion.  There's a book open to a photo of a horse and rider jumping a rail.  Liza closes it, reads:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Equitation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been reading up on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re:  sketches) Are these yours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry nods, embarrassed.  As he staples some papers together, Liza stops short.  In the margin of one of the drawings are two small profile sketches of her.  Eyes closed, it looks like she's sleeping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here it is.  Conspiracy Theory (proudly hands it over) It just went out Tuesday.  Third issue this year.  I bet I struck a nerve.  Pissed someone off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (scans contents) 'The Space Shuttle's Seismic Secret'.  'The Oliver Stone-George Bush Connection'. (looks up) Oliver Stone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stone is their spokesman.  You think if someone really had all that information and a national podium to shout it out from that they'd let him do it?  Stone's a disinformation flunky.  The face that he's alive says it all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you prove any of this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolutely not.  A good conspiracy is an unprovable conspiracy.  If you can figure it out, they screwed it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liza flips through, reads the lead-in to one story aloud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'On July 8, 1979, security forces under control of the Trilateral Commission abducted the fathers of all American Nobel Prize winners. The men, many of them octogenarians, were forced at gunpoint to ejaculate into small plastic bottles.  The sperm collected is now under study in a laboratory beneath the headquarters of the Rand Corporation in Santa Monica, California.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty scary, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... how many subscribers do you have?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (embarrassed) Just five.  It's the economy... You think maybe one of them is not who they seem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a list?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry nods, goes about digging one up.  Liza steps to a bookshelf and fifteen different copies of The Catcher in the Rye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a Holden Caulfield fan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holden Caulfield?  Catcher in the Rye?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never heard of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have ten copies of the book, but you don't know who the main character is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never read it.  I just -- Every time I see one I buy it.  I don't know why exactly... Wanna hear my favorite part?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Strange.  As Liza nods, Jerry opens to a particular page.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reads) 'I keep picturing all these little kids in this big field of rye... And I'm standing on the edge of some crazy cliff...'

dialogues.speaker: FRONT DOOR
dialogues.text: Nothing until, almost imperceptibly, the door knob moves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'If they're running and they don't look where they're going I have to come out from somewhere and catch them.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (finishing) 'That's all I'd do all day.  I'd just be the catcher in the rye.'

dialogues.speaker: FRONT DOOR
dialogues.text: The BOTTLE FALLS as the knob turns.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY'S BEDROOM
dialogues.text: A brief look between them before Jerry hits a switch which kills the lights, then pulls her down alongside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It probably fell by itself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry puts a finger over her lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two black-clad snipers aim at Jerry's window, OPEN FIRE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liza stifles a cry as tear gas canisters CRASH the WINDOW.

dialogues.speaker: FRONT DOOR
dialogues.text: It's bludgeoned open.  Light streams from the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: BUILDING HALLWAY
dialogues.text: Ten black-clad assault team members dives for cover as their leader tosses in a CONCUSSION GRENADE.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY'S LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Cabinets split at the seams as the air is rent by the THUDDING IMPLOSION.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY'S BEDROOM
dialogues.text: A beacon shines through the shattered window, but they're clear.  Jerry shoulders the desk across the floor.  He pulls a barely visible wire loop, opens a trap door in the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Jerry guides Liza down the hatch...

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: The assault team enters military style.

dialogues.speaker: KITCHEN WINDOWS
dialogues.text: Smash as two commandos rappel their way inside.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY'S BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Grabbing the subscriber list, Jerry drops down the hatch pulls the trap door shut behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dark.  Jerry lands alongside Liza on a mattress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Always rent a spare apartment!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Standing, Jerry hauls down on a handle attached to another thin wire.  Really putting his weight into it.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY'S BEDROOM
dialogues.text: The desk slides back into position over the trap door. Just an instant before the assault team rolls in.

dialogues.speaker: DOWNSTAIRS APARTMENT
dialogues.text: Jerry dashes to a closet.  Liza watches as he opens the closet door, strikes a waiting match.  He lights a fuse which burns up toward a hole in the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Getting rid of my hub!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liza stops short.  The white light from the fuse illuminates the Wonderwall.  Liza stares at a 6x12 painted montage.  One image dominates.  In fact, it's arresting. Bliss:  Liza in full equestrian fear, hands outstretched, head thrown back.  Astride a winged horse.  It soars over a gate and up into the heavens. Jerry has eyes only for the fuse.  As it disappears through the hole in the floor, it takes its light with it.  The Wonderwall goes dark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Branching off, the fuse runs into them, through them. Incendiaries ignite.

dialogues.speaker: FILE HALLWAY
dialogues.text: Bursting into flames.  Everywhere.  The assault team members shout, beat a retreat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry pulls a jacket from the closet, starts to pull it on.  It's too dark to make out exactly what he's doing. Liza grabs the matches, lights one.  It casts a barely adequate glow on the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry's wearing a fireman's greatcoat, pulls on a fireman's helmet.  Realizing what she's seen, he's very embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't know.  It was here when I moved in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The match burns to Liza's fingertips.  Darkness once again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No shortage of light up here.  As the last man exit, it's become an incinerator.  White hot flame shoots out. Paint peels.  The housing of the typewriter melts.  A locked METAL CYLINDER on the kitchen counter EXPLODES in a shower of popcorn.  Polaroids blister.  But more than anything -- files burn.  As the sound of SIRENS builds...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smoke, but no fire.  Six NYC firefighters escort squinting residents to the fire escape.  A FIREMAN exits an apartment with a woman slung over his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make a hole.  Watch your backs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Jerry.  The woman is Liza.  As a path is cleared...

dialogues.speaker: STAIRWELL
dialogues.text: Jonas and his men trot up the stairs led by a FIRE CAPTAIN.  Lowry follows, looking like he wished he were someplace else.  Jonas no longer wears the bandage, just a small strip which partially covers the stitches across his nose. They meet Jerry and Liza on the landing, cross right past them.  Oblivious.  Jerry and Liza continue down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was that who I thought it was?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Has this happened to you before?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never, but I've been practicing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat; then...) Who are you, Jerry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a guy trying to put out a fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They continue down OUT OF SIGHT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry dumps the fireman's coat in the trash, jumps in the BMW as Liza TEARS AWAY from the curb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonas and his men are walked through the smoldering ruins by a Fire Captain.  He pauses at the silver on the walls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See the aluminum stuff?  Firewall. Guy designed it so he could turn the place into an incinerator. Leaves the rest of the building untouched.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stepping up) Dr. Jonas, there's something else you should see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
